newsitem.title: NORWAY: Norway oil union threatens August strike.
newsitem.headline: Norway oil union threatens August strike.

text.p: The possibility of a strike action by oil workers on floating production installations on the Norwegian continental shelf increased on Friday following the breakdown of negotiations with employers.

The Federation of Norwegian Oil Workers (OFS) said the probability of a strike at nearly 20 floating units in August was "very high" after it broke off talks with the Norwegian Shipowners Association (NR) at 0400 GMT on Friday.
At the same negotiations, two other oil unions, the Norwegian Oil and Petrochemical Union (NOPEF) and the Cooperation Organisation (DSO), agreed settlements.
OFS has around 1,000 members working on the floating systems. The agreements reached by NOPEF and DSO covers around 2,500 offshore employees.

In a statement, OFS said the dispute centred on a rise in the minimum wage for managers with individual salary agreements, completion of the harmonisation process for terms covering workers on fixed and floating installations, and pension terms.
OFS has 14 days to decide if it will break off its running agreement. If so, there follows a one month "cooling off" period before any action can begin.
It said a strike could result in the shutdown of some oil and gas production after a period of time and also would impact exploration and drilling activity and other support functions.
NR said it regretted it had not come to a solution with OFS, but it was pleased with the settlements reached with NOPEF and DSO.
